reasoning:
The critique targets a specific supporting step in the paper’s broader “no easy eutopia / most plausible views are fussy” case: the bounded, separately-aggregating-goods-and-bads argument that even extremely tiny proportions of bads can block ‘mostly-great’ status. That step matters, but it is only one branch among several (unbounded linear views, approximate linearity of many bounded views, multiplicative fragility examples, etc.), so centrality is moderate rather than high.

Substantively, the critique does put pressure on how the paper operationalizes the ‘tiny fraction of bads’ point: it highlights that mapping “fraction of resources” to “fraction of maximum disvalue” depends on particular scaling/aggregation assumptions, and that some plausible ethical modeling would track integrated suffering intensity/duration rather than physical extent, allowing ‘quarantine/rapid correction’ to prevent small bad regions from counting as massive bad totals. This weakens the rhetorical force and some generality of the 1-in-10^22 illustrative claim.

However, it does not fully refute the underlying structural worry: on many separate-aggregation bounded views with large accessible scale, even small per-unit rates of bads can accumulate to large total bads, so some form of ‘extreme sensitivity to bads at scale’ can persist even if the specific resource-share-to-disvalue mapping is adjusted. The critique is mostly correct and clear, with little fluff, and it remains focused on essentially one issue.
title: Aggregation and scaling assumptions drive the 'tiny bads dominate' claim
